questions.question_text: An engineer must implement QoS to prioritize traffic that requires better service throughout the network. The engineer started by configuring a class map to identify the high-priority traffic. Which additional tasks must the engineer perform to implement the new QoS policy?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer : Option B outlines the necessary steps to complete the QoS implementation after identifying the traffic with the class map.

Option C is not the correct answer because it involves the use of a VRF (Virtual Routing and Forwarding) to segregate the high-priority traffic, which is not typically a standard requirement for implementing a basic QoS policy.

choices.A: Attach the class map to a policy map that sets the minimum bandwidth allocated to the classified traffic and designates the action to be taken on the traffic.
choices.D: Create a route map to manipulate the routes that are entered into the routing table and then attach the route map to an interface using a service policy.
choices.C: Attach the class map to a policy map within a VRF to segregate the high-priority traffic and then attach the policy map to an interface in another VRF.
choices.B: Attach the class map to a policy map that designates the action to be taken on the classified traffic and then attach the policy map to an interface using a service policy.

choices.A: An engineer must identify the prefix list with a number only.
choices.B: The final entry in a prefix list must be /32.
choices.C: An engineer must include only the prefixes for which he needs to log activity.
choices.D: An engineer must use nonsequential sequence numbers in the prefix list so that he can insert additional entries later.

questions.question_text:
An engineer working for telecommunication company needs to secure the LAN network using a prefix list.
Which best practice should the engineer follow when he implements a prefix list?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
This question asks for best practice and using nonsequential sequence numbers is the only BP I can see listed. So answer should be “D”.
C. pois a pergunta se trata de segurança.

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct

Selected Answer: D
C is incorrect , Prefix lists are primarily used for filtering and controlling traffic flow, not for logging activity. While it is possible to configure a prefix list to log activity, it is not a best practice to include only the prefixes for which activity needs to be logged.

Selected Answer: C
C would be the best answer

When working with Prefix Lists, you have to include the exact network prefix found in your routing table, but that's not a "best practice" action, is a MUST, otherwise your traffic is not matched.
Option D. is correct. That is a good practice action, but not a requirement for the prefix list to work.
Later on as your network grow, you might need to implement new statements in the existing prefix list, so using non-sequential numbers gives you the ability to insert numbers in between without deleting the whole prefix list and recreating it.

Selected Answer: D
Similarly to access-lists, having sequence numbers allows you easily to add or remove individual lines. If you leave some space between them you can insert additional lines where you need them and don't have to resequence them. I just don't understand the suggestions for C unless the options have changed. 

None of the other options are correct in my opinion. 
My vote is:
D. An engineer must use nonsequential sequence numbers in the prefix list so that he can insert additional entries later.

Selected Answer: C
C looks OK

D might not be the best.
I see option D more about Access-lists.
Option C, however is more accurate due to prefix-lists filter entire network ranges just based on prefix lengths.

Selected Answer: AD
NNHOP means node-protection. As we have two transit nodes, we need to take into consideration what happens when they go down. These two are R2 and R5.

If R2 goes down, we need to go R6 --> R1 --> R4 --> R5 (This is the fastest)

If R5 goes down, we need to go R6 --> R2 --> R1 --> R4 --> XR1 --> XR2
The reason for this is becasue R2 is going to be the one who detects that R5 went down so it will re-reoute the traffic, even though there would be a better path.

Selected Answer: AD
I agree, NNHOP provide node protetion , since the primary path from R6 to XR2 pass through R2 and R5 , the role of bgp autotunnel with NNHOP is to protect the LSP in case one of those two nodes fails, 
-option A provide protection of LSP in case of R5 fails 
-option D provide protection of LSP in case of R2 fails
-options B, C and E dont provide a protection in case of R2 or R5 fails , so are all wrong

comments.content: can you please tell why not B

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer configured R6 as the headend LSR of an RSVP-TE LSP to router XR2, with the dynamic path signaled as R6-R2-R5-XR2, and set the OSPF cost of all links to 1. MPLS autotunnel backup is enabled on all routers to protect the LSP. Which two NNHOP backup tunnels should the engineer use to complete the implementation? (Choose two.)

choices.D: The R6 backup tunnel path R6-R1-R4-R5.
choices.E: The R6 backup tunnel path R6-R1-R2.
choices.C: The R6 backup tunnel path R6-R2-R5.
choices.B: The R2 backup tunnel path R2-R5 across the alternate link.
choices.A: The R2 backup tunnel path R2-R1-R4-XR1-XR2.

discussion.content:
B is correct

Command is "show ip ospf nsr "

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/iproute_ospf/configuration/15-e/iro-15-e-book/iro-nsr-ospf.pdf

choices.C: Reset OSPF neighbor sessions to maintain state information during router switchover.
choices.A: Increase the keepalive interval on the OSPF neighbors so that traffic continues to pass during the switchover.
choices.D: Configure the device to repopulate state information using routing updates received from the BDR.
choices.B: Ensure that the dual RP has synchronized their state information before performing the switchover operation.

questions.question_text: An engineer is implementing NSR with OSPF on a large campus that requires high availability. Which task must an engineer perform to complete the process with minimal disruption to traffic?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/optical/ncs1001/telemetry/guide/b-telemetry-cg-ncs1000/configure-model-driven-telemetry.html

Configuration with tls-hostname:
Router(config)#telemetry model-driven
Router(config-model-driven)#destination-group DGroup2
Router(config-model-driven-dest)#address family ipv4 172.0.0.0 port 57500
Router(config-model-driven-dest-addr)#encoding self-describing-gpb
Router(config-model-driven-dest-addr)#protocol grpc tls-hostname hostname.com
Router(config-model-driven-dest-addr)#commit

D looks correct but the command is not quite right, possibly a typo:

Command is 
protocol grpc tls-hostname <> (NOT tis-hostname...)

questions.question_text: A service provider requires continuous real-time network monitoring to provide reliable SLAs to its customers. To satisfy this requirement, a network administrator is implementing gRPC dial out on an ASR with TLS. Receiver 192.168.10.2 will be assigned one of the subscriptions, and it will manage the ASR. Which configuration must the engineer apply to the router as part of the configuration process?

choices.A: snmp-server community public snmp-server enable traps snmp-server host 192.168.10.2 version 2c public.
choices.B: telemetry model-driven destination-group DGroup1 address family ipv4 192.168.10.2 1 port 10 encoding self-describing-gpb
choices.D: telemetry model-driven destination-group ciscotest address family ipv4 192.168.10.2 port 10 encoding self-describing-gpb protocol grpc tis-hostname ciscotest.com
choices.C: snmp-server community public snmp-server enable traps snmp-server enable traps snmp authentication snmp-server manager snmp-server manager session-timeout 1000
